DataElementConcept.preferredName: Large Cell Lung Carcinoma Histologic Subtype
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A poorly differentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation.  There is a male predilection._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.A group forming a type within a larger type.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A poorly differentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation.  There is a male predilection.

Concepts.definition: An undifferentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular, squamous, or neuroendocrine differentiation.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to histology.:Subtype; a group forming a type within a larger type.

A group forming a type within a larger type.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Large Cell Lung Carcinoma Histology Specify
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text description of the histologic subtype used to refine and specify a diagnosis of large cell lung cancer.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Large Cell Lung Carcinoma Histology Specify
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A poorly differentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation.  There is a male predilection.:The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Be specific about something; define clearly.

Concepts.definition: An undifferentiated non-small cell lung carcinoma composed of large polygonal cells without evidence of glandular, squamous, or neuroendocrine differentiation.

The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
Be specific about something; define clearly.
